reviewText:
It's super broke but at least they ported the correct generation this time, hopefully this arcane knowledge carries into their future ports.

- For some reason it supports DirectInput but not Xinput for gamepads. In other words, your 360 controller (or most modern controllers that don't have a switch) won't work without some 3rd party finagling, but your old cheap controllers will.
- Default controller bindings are extremely awkward
- Also getting the crashes early into first map.
- Configuration app defaults to Japanese but can change it to English by going into the 2nd tab, selecting English in dropdown box, then clicking the middle button. The left button resets all settings and the far right button cancels all config.
- Does not technically support Borderless Windowed but seems to work without issue with the Borderless Gaming app.
- What the hell are these activation keys for?
- Forgot to add, when you create a mercenary you can enter a name but it won't let you use the keyboard normally. The controls in general for navigating the creation menu are also awkward.

Probably worth getting once patched but until then, don't do it man. If they fix the issues I'd change the recommendation.

reviewText:
In Bladestorm: Nightmare the player is called to create a mercenary and accept missions which will advance the English or the French cause in the course of the Hundred Years War. The successful completion of these missions relies on a variety of elements which put the player’s fighting abilities, strategy, tactical and leadership skills to the test. The Mercenary does not ride to the field alone, but as the commander of an army unit selected to fit each individual situation as some missions are better fought with foot soldiers, others with lances, archers, light cavalry, or a combination of melee, ranged and mounted units.

The Problem at the moment is that the game is just crashing every time ( in the battles , after the battles , loading screens )

Don`t buy it at the moment . Wait a few months until Koei has fixed some crashes .

reviewText:
Let's start with the games is optimised fairly badly so if you don't have a powerful machine it will not run well. I have a high end graphics card with a powerful CPU and on max settings I still don't get a guarenteed 60 FPS. The game on launch is in Japanese but there is a community guide on how to change it on steam.

The price is also a big negative however as no game should really be at this price and not be able to last the test of time. If it is on sale I recommend it, but as it is I would say wait for a sale.

First of all if you have played the original Bladestorm it is fairly similar but looks better has another campaign as well as a few new mechanics and features.

Secondly, the setting. It is based in a very romanticised version of the 100 years war so it will have troops which weren't present such as ninjas, barbarians and magic. Do not expect a realistic game it is Koei Tecmo.

Thirdly, the game allows you to select units into battle and later on you got take extra commanders in and form armies.

Finally difficulty, as it stands there is almost no difficulty. If you want to speed through the game go through the nightmare mode untill you get guns and then go through a few missions with as many commanders as you can with guns form an army and victory is easy. You can use the same character in the other campaign and keep the previously gained levels books and pages.

Pro -
New army and commander system
Large Maps
Freedom to ignore orders and charge into random castles and villages to capture
Many different unit types to choose from
2 campaigns to choose from
Nightmare mode is interesting with the fantasy elements and still in the period of the 100 years war, not many games allow you to charge across the French country side with a horde of goblins

Cons -
Crap optimisation
Sometimes units bug out and combat doesn't work right
AI pathfinding messes up and some units will get caught on scenery or a random huge guy which I am sure is meant to be in nightmare mode appears in the normal game
Overpriced

reviewText:
I loved Bladestorm on Playstation 3, I wanted to love it on PC too, but there are just so many problems with the engine that Koei has used that it is barely playable for anyone who uses a decent nVidia GPU, so unplayable that you'll be spending a lot of your playtime trying to figure out how to fix the issue or booting the game back up when it's decided to randomly crash either before battle, mid battle, after battle or when you get to tavern.

I personally, do not care about the graphics, I don't care that they don't look as good as current generation games, I could accept the frame drops in battles, hell, I'd even accept the odd crash here and there; but not every battle, or every other battle, or every 20 - 30 minutes I get to play. Steam's refund policy came after this was released, so a lot of us got stung by that, because we spend more then '2 hours' trying to find a way to play the game, or we waited desperately for Koei to say something, but they didn't.

Instead, they moved on to Toukiden: Kiwami, another Playstation 4 Port, where they then said they found an issue with certain nVidia cards. Then, the reports came in again, from nVidia users, that they have constant crashing issues, including owners that are not on the list of the cards listed to have a problem. Like Bladestorm, the issues where with 'Windows 8.1' and yet the game is listed to be compatable with 'Windows 8.1' but if you own certain cards, by nVidia, you have to run it in Windows 7 to get it to work... if you're so lucky.

Then you had the fixes, rolling back drivers to older ones, Windows 7 Compatability, turning everything down to low, turning things off. It's not acceptable and as someone who has followed Koei's releases on Consoles way back from Dynasty Warriors 2, I find it extremely saddening that Koei are giving us PC Gamers, games that are unstable, broken or extremely restricted to certain hardware. It isn't fair, especially with the price they're asking and it isn't right; and despite being a fan of Koei's games, I'd honestly say that if Bladestorm and Kiwami are what we can expect to get from them, then avoid unless you have an AMD Card, or one of the few nVidia GPU's that seem to be working without issue.

Or, you have Windows 7. God help us when Windows 10 comes out.
voteText: 29 of 37 people (78%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Vastly improved over the Xbox 360 title (Bladestorm: The Hundred Years' War), Bladestorm: Nightmare adds a few things that make the Nightmare experience oh so sweet.  Noteable changes to the original game include the ability to save multiple custom Mercenaries, merge armies with squadmates, and a completely revamped base commander system for the larger conquest points.

Included in this version of the game is both a Nightmare campaign and a Free mode, neither of which were present in the original title.

Bladestorm Nightmare is the best version of Bladestorm: The Hundred Years' War and if you've got a decent PC, this version of Bladestorm Nightmare is the best version.  I have seen the reports of problems, but I have yet to experience those same problems, so I'm giving the game a thumbs up for being a huge improvement over an already great game.

reviewText: Sorry to hear it runs poorly for a lot of people, but on my fully AMD setup--R9 270x GPU, Vishera 8350 CPU, Win7 x64, 16GB RAM--the game runs flawlessly on all High settings (with Vsync turned off).  Played ~6 hours now, a dozen or so missions, not one crash or big FPS drop.\n\nThat said--PLAY WITH A CONTROLLER.  I normally love KB+M but it just does not work on this game.  If you've got a controller, this is exactly the PS3 gem of 7 years ago, with nice improvements and additions.  Bladestorm is the only Dynasty Warriors style game I enjoy since you have to pay attention to your squad and the battlefield both within your area and at large.  Many hours of tactical, badass fun.

reviewText: It isn't a good port, but it is a good game.  Once I got the game into Windows 7 compatibility mode to stop the crashes and figured out what the gamepad controls are I've been having good fun with it.  It's a lot like the standard Tecmo-Koei Musou games, but with just a tiny push towards being more realistic by having you attack with your troops instead of being a one-man murder machine.  You get to be a mercenary leader in the Hundred Years War, and you just grab a group of people with whatever weapon is good against the bad guys in front of you and smash them up, it's fun.

reviewText:
---PC PORT REVIEW---
Cons:
- 30 FPS locked.
- Gibberish external config tool.
- Unskippable intro logos.
- Game launches JPN exe by default, not the English one.
- No choice between AA.
- No console button prompts.
- No bechmark tool.
- Pre-rendered FMV cutscenes.

Pros:
- Ported from current gen version.
- Support up to 4K resolution.
- Extensive graphic options.
- Eng/Jpn voice overs,

Despite the cons outweighing the pros, the fact this is based on the current gen version, has extensive graphic options, a nice character creation system and arguably awesome gameplay to boot, a few mods/patches can fix these issues. I recommend this PC port, hope to see more!
voteText: 235 of 444 people (53%) found this review helpful 31 people found this review funny

reviewText: For those of you still searching for a solution to the crashes, I've been playing it for the past hour and half and it seems to be working. Change the compatibility for the game to windows 7, turn off shaders and change the the definition to about 1300 or 1600. To do so, simple find where steam has your games (for this game usually C:\Steam\SteamApps\common\BLADESTORM Nightmare) and then right-click on all four of the exe files, go onto compatibility, then click the box for run the program for compatibility mode for: and choose windows seven. Then click the box to run as administrator, then finally click apply and start the game up.

reviewText: I was a bit weary buying this game after seeing all the bad reviews, but so far, I'm pleasantly surprised by the game. I was a huge fan of Bladestorm on the 360, but the lack of co-op kind of sucked. I have played almost all of the Musou games with my brother and the funnest part was definitely the co-op. I started playing this game with a friend of mine and I am happy with it so far. I have a GTX 970 and with all the settings maxed, I have a steady 60 FPS, the only exception was the tutorial. We've played a good few hours, and neither of us have experienced any crashes or major issues. If I'm to offer any advice, it's that if you want to play storyline missions with your friends, they have to have them unlocked as well, so you may have to switch hosts and grind renown sometimes. Also, no split screen co-op, so keep it in mind. Conclusion: If you love Dynasty Warriors or Kingdom Under Fire games, pick this up, but for the best experience, play it with a friend.

reviewText:
Bladestorm is great because you get to watch everyone worship Joan of Arc for her heroic deeds while you pretend like she's not just going to be burned at the stake like some common witch at some point in her immediate future.

Also, the additional Nightmare mode this port is known for is really good, and you get to realize that the events of Soul Calibur begin because Joan of Arc thought humanity should believe in themselves.  Silly teenagers.

The ports a bit wonky if you turn off vsync and starts crashing, so if you dislike 30 FPS then get ready for a lot of reloading.  Also, the game is pretty average, so expect slightly more strategic Dynasty Warriors.

Also, get Rogue Ninjas, because they are the best.

reviewText:
[Will update this review as I progress through the game]

Bladestorm is a weird mash between Total War and Musou game, very weird to control at first but super fun once you learn how everything works. This port isn't as bad as some of the reviews will lead you to believe (PS4 port instead of PS3, online multiplayer included) but still has some issues to improve on. Koei doesn't patch their games 90% of the time so these issues won't be fixed but if you're willing to look past some minor flaws that don't hamper gameplay much its a enjoyable and rather lengthy game:

- No controller button prompts
- Somewhat poor optimization, average framerate is about 40-50 FPS maxed out with a GTX 970 and FX-8370
- Some cutscenes have broken or missynced subtitles (The opening to both Story modes for example)
- Prerendered cutscenes have japanese text instead of english text if you have the JP voice option selected
- If you have a 144hz monitor if you cut Vsync on 1 or 2 instead of 0 some menus run at double game speed
- Will crash alot unless you have Windows 7 compatibility mode turned on

reviewText:
So far, so good.

Only encountered one crash during gameplay. When I ran the game again, and looked for save files, it seems there was a mid-battle autosave, so I didn't lose all of my progress. You also have the option of being able to manually save in battle, so crashes are more of a minor annoyance. Like I said though, I've only had one crash so far. I should also mention I have Win7 64-bit. It seems people are having problems with OS's higher than it, and have to set it up for Win7 compatibility.

Aside from that, I have no complaints. I would suggest waiting for a sale, because the full price tag is a bit steep IMO. I got it for 60% off, and consider it to be good value considering what the game has to offer. You basically can swap units, depending on what situation you find yourself in. Every troop has their weakness, so it pays to learn which units are most effective against others.

It seems this game has quite a bit to offer. I played the original Bladestorm on PS3, so if they've added another full campaign, then the content alone woudl warrant a purchase when it's on sale at a good price.

Edit:

After playing about 10 hours, i definitely give this game a thumbs up. Been lots of fun switching from unit to unit, in order to exploit the enemy army's weaknesses.

reviewText:
I noticed that there were a lot of complaints from other reviews sayng they had major crashing and/or lag.
It also seemed like a lot of the positive reviews from those who were not suffering had full or mostly AMD systems.

I decided to bite the bullet and try to see if I could run it with no problems.

I have a fully non-AMD system and I have not had a single instance in which the game had crashed or lagged so I figured I'd post this is to let everyone know that if you do have Intel & NVIDIA you still might be able to run the game.

Of course I am aware that I have a very expensive system but again this is to counter the idea that AMD will only work with this game.

Specs:

-Windows 7 64-Bit

-Intel Core i7 4790K    (4.0 GHz with 4.4GHz turbo, Quad Core, Multithreading, Hyperthreading)

-16GB RAM at 1866MHz

-GIGABYTE NVIDIA Geforce GTX 970 4GB  GDDR5   (On a PCI-e x16 serial bus, of course)

I only recommend this game to people who understand the tags are Hack and Slash and Strategy and have seen actual gameplay and still want to play it."

reviewText:
This one is a really touchy subject. Yes, a lot of people are having performance issues and quite a bit of crashing, and the steep price are definetly things to consider. Does the game really add all that much to justify the problems? I feel it's going to be situational depending on the player. If you can get the game to run at an acceptable level, and are enough of a fan of the old ps/xbox release that you are willing to spend the money (which I do believe to be a little ridiculous), they you will surely enjoy this slightly expanded illiteration.

I've yet to play the nightmare campaign, but I know if you fufill certain conditions you can unlock units from nightmare to play in your 100YW side of the game, which is a bonus. Along with that comes a greatly improved character creator, with the option to use multiple created characters in your campaign as well as send them off to earn you money and equipment while you play your main/do something else.

You should probably wait until this one goes on sale, or gets some patches for the crashing people are experiencing. But on a decent rig, theres a good chance you might not experience any problems. Worse comes to worse, Steam has just updated their refund policy, so if you just bought it and havent been playing (or trying to play it) for more than 2h, you can just get a refund. Happy Storming.

reviewText:
You'll see a lot of whining about the graphics and crashing issues in the reviews on this game. Not here. Personally, anything that crashes has fixes, it's the nature of PC gaming.

The reason I don't reccommend this game is because it's NOT a PC game.

It's a bad playstation port of what could otherwise be a wonderful game. However, the controls are set terribly to Keyboard & Mouse, and it offers -NO- reasonable tutorial. It pretends to offer a tutorial, but adds arbitrary labels to keys instead of telling you what key is assigned to a function, leaving you fumbling around in hopes of figuring out how to even attack. The only way to mitigate this is to actually go into the controls screen in the main menu options and read every. single. keybind.

On top of that, your mouse is not only useless, it will prevent you from playing the game. I actually had to take my hand -off- of the mouse to keep the game from tabbing out, because it minimized if I ever left or right clicked. To top it off, the camera isn't bound to any mouse functions, so there is absolutely no point to ever use your mouse for this game. Your keyboard is all of the controls, and it's even clumsier than a controller.

I found myself so frustrated with this game after just the first two missions, I had to quit. Maybe I'll come back with a controller when I'm craving a console experience, but if that was what they wanted to offer, BLADESTORM would have been better off staying on the Playstation.

reviewText:
I'm going to start with a few simple statements. I love Bladestorm.

I love nearly every game Koei makes.

I will never buy another game of theirs for the PC.


When a game offers a configuration menu when you try to start it, I like to take a look at it, drop all the setting to their lowest, and go up from there. I couldn't even read it. I had to spend four minutes trying to find the setting that changed the language to english. I felt that things could only go up from there. I was wrong.

I beat the recommended system requirements, so it stands to reason the game will be playable. In the Hundred Years War mode (the old bladestorm story basically) you start in the bar. I wasn't paying too much attention, but the fact everyone was missing their skin texture was pretty obvious off the bat, and also vaguely amusing. The single-digit framerate wasn't though. Despite putting twenty minutes into it, I was unable to get through the bar.

I'll gladly recommend this game. Just not on PC.

Warning person here might be highly BIAS for this game due to bladestorm on the original 360 being one of my most played games on that console and that i wanted a new one on pc just to go over the top with soldier units.

reviewText:
The game has already been released back in 2006 and recieved a new makeup on Steam as well as on PS4 and XBox One.

I bought and played the Xbox 360 version a few months back and I enjoyed the game. On the Xbox 360 the game sometimes simply froze and I lost 30-60 minutes of gametime which made playing this game very frustrating sometimes.

For fans of Koei games I can be very Brief: This game is a mix between Dynasty Warriors and Kessen. It has more strategic elements than Dynasty Warriors because you decide which troups you command or if you go all out by yourself (usually not recommended). There are certain strategic points you should follow but also can achieve a victory by your own strategy. Some quests however demand to follow a certain order to siege on enemy camps.
There is also more action than in the previous Kessen games though the game is less story driven. You have more command not only over your own charakter but also over your troups which you can switch during battle. The difference to Kessen is that your ally npc generals will always be played by the computer and you cannot controll those.
There are a lot cutscenes telling the main story of the hundred years war and its interesting to fight either side of the French or British Kingdom. The skills you can use depend on which troops you command and there are so many different troops you can unlock during the game. Same goes for armor and weapon.
The graphics look far better than the ones of Dynasty Warriors Empire or Xtreme Legends.
You will probably start the game on Japanese settings but it has in fact a good English translation for both voices and menu/subtitles if you start the game with the English -exe in the Steamapp folder. I personaly enjoy the new Nightmare mode a lot since it gives the game not only a good makeover but also a new story element similiar to the Orochi series.

________________________________________________________________

For people who arent familiar with Tecmo Koei games (do they even exist? lol kidding):

This game is a mix between an action and a strategy rpg set during the Hundred years war in France.

You can create your own officer and have already plenty of options to chose from gender, voices, hairstyle, bodyshape etc.
Once you finally created a char which might take you quite a while you start as a mercenary for either the French or British Kingdom and the first battle serves as a tutorial which explaines you the games mechanics. Mainly you have to take controll over a huge range of troops such as spearsmen, swordsmen, archers, lancers and many more. You cannot controll all of the different troops at once but have to first get a command book unlocking that ability.
You also can buy weapons, armor and other upgrades or level up your or your troops skills at the local tavern after you return from a battle. Before, during or after a battle some cutscenes tell the story. Some battles will only serve as a way to get more experience and gold while others will let you progress with the story. The difficulty also sometimes can be chosen depending on the battle you join.

I suggest you use a compatible controller because gameplay might be a bit smoother but that is up to you. I will not review the performance of the game since I do not have a high end gaming pc. Some ppl say they can run a decent 60 fps while other struggle to get 30 and say its badly optimized. You better ask in the forum, let ppl know your pc specs and wait for some feedback before buying the game if you worry about performance.

The game in my opinion is a lot of fun and you can have a lot of hours playing through the story mode. There is another fantasy like mode called nightmare mode including midevil fantasy creatures such as goblins and dragons which give you again a huge amount of gaming time. The graphics arent the most advanced but they are solid and good to look at. I can recommend this game and if you enjoy a game with an action, rpg, strategy mix made by Japanese devs, you wont be wrong with this title. If you cannot make up your mind by watching the screenshots and some trailers/youtube videos I simply suggest you try out a sale. I got this game for about 60% off (23,99 Euros). I didnt regret the purchase.

reviewText: The game has an amazing concept, and I respect that, it was a entertaining game on the xbox, where I played the original BLADESTORM. But I feel they have not put in any effort in porting it towards steam and the pc. At first I spent about half an hour attempting to click random buttons to change the game to english, a understandable struggle as the company is not english and that is a respectable decision for them. Afterwards I noticed that the game was almost a direct port from xbox, asking us to push buttons from the controller here, and not telling us the actual keys to press on the keyboard. The gameplay is fair enough, even though I myself feel they have strayed from the original mechanics with leveling and squad control, I feel that could be more enjoyable towards the public.\n\nCONCLUSION: BLADESTORM: Nightmare is a good game that has not recieved the proper attention it needs in order to port it and could be fixed but I see no sign of it.

reviewText:
Oh the Nostalgia!!

Admittedly the game does crash on average once an hour for me,  but these are problems that will be patched out.
Crashes aside, this game is just a trip down memory lane with some awesome new features like joining units to form an army. Anyone familiar to a Koei game expects the terrible background visuals of the PS2 era, however the updated models do look great in comparison to 2007's Bladestorm: The hundred Years Wars.

Wait for the game to have a couple patches, then play it if you're a fan of the Warriors series or Total War. It's a fun balance of both.

Enjoy.

reviewText: Maybe my computer is crap, but I've never seen this hit over 15fps outside of anything but an options menu or loading screen even on the lowest settings. In addition, throughout every cutscene, the animations play at one tenth the speed of the audio, turning a 10 second conversation into nearly two minutes of watching a facial expresion change. Maybe my system can't handle it, or maybe there's a problem with my copy, but even reinstalls havent fixed any part of it. I dont recommend picking this up quite yet.\nThat aside, the gameplay I've seen thus far has seemed at least fairly simple, and the story doesn't seem too complex, but fun nonetheless, but as I haven't had much of a chance to see much a game, I am naturally biased because of such frustrations. perhaps it may work for you, but i recommend waiting to see if there are patches to fix the above in case this isnt an isolated issue.

reviewText: I have been playing this game for over an hour now. I must say it is a very fun game and I quite enjoy it. I have seen other reviews saying quite negative things that almost got me to not buy it, but I am glad I bought it anyway. No issues with the game. Playing at max settings and achieving 60 FPS. The game looks decent for the type of game it is and very enjoyable. Love the combat and how much there is to do in this game.\n\nOnly thing I dislike is there is no option to change icons to the controller settings. I use a Xbox One controller to play this game, but it only shows mouse / keyboard buttons. I tried out the demo for this game on my Xbox One, but bought it for PC instead.

reviewText: I almost didn't get this game due to the mixed reviews. But I went ahead anyway and I'm glad I did, When I installed the game, I wasn't able to play because the screen would turn black while in map or in the tavern. I thought I made a huge mistake. But before I got crazy, I messed with the graphical settings and solved my issue. I had to turn off reflection completely and now the game runs flawlessly. This may not fix every issue, but it worked for me. That is a bit annoying to have to do, and to be fair $60 is a bit steep for this game, but if you are a fan of the console version of the hundred years war, you get that plus a whole new campaign in nightmare. I recommend this game to fans, not someone just looking for something new. Also be willing to mess around with the graphical settings. I am running the game on high everything but with reflection off. That solved my issue where I could hear the game sound but see only black and tares of color. Hope this helps.

reviewText:
It's an odd game. Mostly action with a smattering of strategy. From what I can see the strategy mostly comes in deciding which order to level up your troops, but they'll all end up leveled up anyway eventually.

It ultimately gets a thumbs up just because it's good plain fun. Wait to get it on sale, though.

It is poorly optimized and so the system requirements are silly. They're not as bad as they're written, so don't be afriad to experiment. For reference I'm running it fine on a Core2Quad 9650 with 960 GTX. I average in the 30s on high even in the thick of things. It should be better, but it's playable.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I played the original Bladestorm: A Hundred Years War on Xbox 360 and I loved it. This new version brings back memories even though at times you can see that this is not the best port ever done. The game refuses to recognize my Xbox controller, I can't use my mouse to control camera and actions, the tutorial doesn't tell you what the button is if you use keyboard so you need to go to the main menu to be able to check the controls and edit them because the default key binds suck. But all in all the game is entertaining and it has a japanese voice acting if you find your ears bleeding after hours of hilarious English voice actors and French accents.

reviewText:
So most of the negative reviews mention that this game is good, but a bad port. So yeah, I agree the game is great, hence I will just mention the port part.

So, with Microsoft finally giving a deadline on Windows 10, I felt like it was time to upgrade and test all my badports. I was on 8.1 before and it worked pretty much fine, but I heard Win10 had lots of incompatibilities, though learning more about the GPU market, I found out they were probably just nVidia driver issues, and I have an AMD GPU, recently upgraded to a R9 380 from a HD7770 x2.

The game runs on all max settings pretty much fine, haven't tested 60fps because I don't care, being properly playable is all I want, and that happens, and no Win10 problems fortunately, everything worked out of the box, the only difference being a Prompt Command windows that didn't close on Win10.
